description: Details required by Condition 4 Part 8 (New Roof for Lambeth Coal Store) of Listed Building Consent 19/01212/LBC (Alterations and extensions of existing student Seething Wells Campus to provide additional student accommodation and ancillary facilities. Rooftop extensions to existing buildings to provide 159 new student rooms, alterations to Listed Buildings to provide a caf√©, flexible meeting and recreation spaces and other ancillary facilities)
decision_conditions: The details submitted for Condition 4 Part 8 (New Roof for Lambeth Coal Store) of Listed Building Consent 19/01212/LBC by the applicant are considered satisfactory and this condition is hereby fully discharged.

The site comprises a semi-detached dwelling.Six neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations have been received. The key areas of assessment are: - The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: Officers note that the current application is a revision of previously refused application ref: 20/02596/HOU. The principle issue with the refused application was the first floor side extension, which would have resulted in a terracing effect. The first floor side extension has been removed from the current proposal thereby addressing this issue. The current application proposes a hip-to-gable conversion, and while this would not respect the symmetry of the adjoining property as recommended by the Residential Design Guide SPD, officers note there are examples of similar developments on the streetscene. As such the proposed hip-to-gable conversion would not appear an incongruous addition to the Endway streetscene. The proposed front porch infill extension would extend to a relatively modest depth, however it is unclear as to what the roof form would be. While the submitted proposed elevation plans show a hipped roof form, the proposed floor plans show a flat roof form. Therefore, while the depth is considered acceptable, officers note that it is not possible to assess the impact that the proposed porch infill extension would have on the Endway streetscene.Officers note that similar inconsistencies are found with the dimensions on the proposed single storey rear and side extension. While the submitted proposed ground floor plan shows that the depth of the rear extension would be just over 4m in depth, the proposed side elevation shows a rear extension with a depth of around 3m. Further inconsistencies are also shown on the plans in regard to the height and roof form of the proposed rear and side elevation. While the proposed side elevation plan shows a part parapet roof and flat roof, the proposed floor plans and rear elevation shows a pitched roof. Therefore, given the inconsistencies shown within the plans provided, officers cannot fully assess whether the proposed development would be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. Officers cannot therefore conclude that the proposed development would not have any unacceptable adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area.Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance. Officer Comment: As mentioned above, the plans provided do not accurately show the proposed depth of the rear extension. Given that the height and roof form of the proposed rear/side extension is also unclear, officers cannot accurately assess the impact the proposed rear and side extension would have to the amenities of the neighbouring properties. Furthermore, given that a proposed west side elevation has not been provided it is unclear what specific effect the rear extension would have to neighbouring property No.28 Endway.Therefore, due to the fact that there are numerous inconsistencies with the plans provided, it cannot be determined that the proposed development would not have any unacceptable adverse impact on the amenities of the adjoining neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.In conclusion, given the inconsistencies of the plans provided, the proposed development would not be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2019), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).Therefore it is recommended that this proposal be refused.

Please provide revise copies of proposed elevation C at a recognised scale of 1:50 or 1:100, providing a scale bar, showing all elevations not just part and indicating all key dimensions for the proposed work.The Proposed Elevation C is labelled as Existing Elevation C in the submitted drawing.
